Dundee workshop to learn about helping those who hear voices
11 April 2007

Hearing voices in your head is much more common than many Scots think
column2: and may be better dealt with by coping strategies than with medication
column3:
a workshop in Dundee will be told next week.

The University of Abertay Dundee and the Fife-based mental health consultancy Working to Recovery Ltd
column4: co-directed by Ron Coleman and Karen Taylor who have an international reputation for their work in recovery and psychosis
column5:
are collaborating on a two-day workshop entitled âTalking to Voicesâ (18/19 April).

The workshop will introduce mental health workers to the relatively new technique of âvoice dialoguingâ
column6:
which aims to help people who find their voices distressing to learn to live with and manage their voices rather than wasting time in an often fruitless quest for a âcureâ.

Dutch research suggests that as many as one in 25 people hear voices or other âauditory hallucinations that have no physical origin in the outside worldâ. For some
column7:
the phenomenon is not linked to mental illness and can sometimes be a pleasant or reassuring experience.

However
column8: for others the voices can be threatening or disturbing â creating anxiety
column9: despair and fear. Often the voices carry some personal significance for the hearer
column10: usually related to some intense emotional event in their past
column11:
such as sexual abuse in childhood. Voices can therefore have a great deal of power over the hearer.

Examples include victims of sexual abuse who hear the voice of their abuser or the voice of a screaming child that represents the abusedâs inability to scream out their pain at the time they were abused.

Voice-dialoguing focuses on helping voice-hearers to explore the history of their voices
column12: and to identify the individuals their voices represent and the things that trigger them. Having done this
column13: the voice hearer is encouraged to engage with their voices in a way in which they
column15: are in control. For some people
column16: this can result in the voices going altogether. For others
column17:
the voices become less distressing and more manageable.

column18: who works in the Hearing Voices Project of the University of Maastricht and is involved in treatment for voice-hearers.  Dr Corstens developed the treatment programme
column20:
and is an active researcher in this field.

The workshop also features Clinical Psychologist Rufus May from the Bradford Assertive Outreach Team. He has an interest in promoting self-help and recovery processes in psychosis. His ideas and thinking are influenced by in his own experiences of being a psychiatric patient when he was 18 years old.
